reviews.review_msg: He is really not as bad as people say, he always gave a clear idea of what was going to be on the exams and the tests were very fair too. Lectures can be kinda dry but he explains concepts quite well and is super helpful in office hours.

had him in fall24 and he wasn't as bad as the reviews say on here. lectures do get really boring but the exams imo were fair. he gave us some of the long answer questions in advance so we could prepare which honestly helped a lot. he also gives hints on what the essay questions could be. overall not a bad professor and a really nice person.
When I spoke with him about final paper, he was not as bad as others have noted.

Lectures were long and dry, and most of them were cancelled due to the strike and his personal matters which were mostly reasonable, but he ended up throwing the slides on canvas and calling it a day. He gave lots of slides but they were difficult to understand on their own without him explaining further. That being said, his tests were very fair.

Plus there is no textbook for this class making it even harder to keep up when there is literally no lectures pretty much the entire semester. And theres pretty much no point in asking him a question his answer is pretty much always 'is that ethical though'.

This class was a joke. As a health science major this class is a required course to graduate therefore I was expecting to learn something, but it was quite the opposite. We only had 3 lectures over the course of the semester, he would constantly cancel class the day off
(1/8)

His lecture slides are so dense, they're like pages to some essay. He unnecessarily complicates concepts and repeats his slides in class. The tutorials also don't really teach anything; the TA's expect you to know the content and then apply them in presentations but you don't really get feedback. The grading criteria is also confusing sometimes.

Not a good prof, but certainly not the worst. He adapts his class based on feedback and was fair considering the strikes. This class is really not very hard, you just need to understand the concepts. When a prof is slacking, students stop trying. It takes some motivation but you can get a good grade, no need to fear this class as others say.

He seems like a very nice person but the lectures were not it. Everything was so dense and it was hard to follow along for most of the time. The TA's were also horrible - I would try and avoid if possible

I have no idea if he is a good lecturer as I have only seen him 3 times in person. He seems nice but doesn't know how to teach this class properly and does not have a clear plan for it either. Super long lecture slides. Tutorials are mandatory but I never got the point as you don't really learn much, just pointless small group work each time.

Long lecture slides, some of it is directly copy-pasted from Google. Slides are unnecessarily wordy and long. Not concise and difficult to follow along when it's just a whole textbook chapter pasted onto slides.

I took this class a year ago but decided to come back and let you know I still think about this man and how every time u as. him a question-the answer is its "its unethical" . I will rant about this man till I am in my grave

The lectures are very dense with material and I feel that they do not need to be. I think the prof should focus on one CLEAR definition that he likes rather than having many slides of definitions defining the same concepts. The grading criteria for the midterms and papers are not explicit.

Avoid it at all costs and terrible experience for sure. His lecture is so dull that he just go through his 90+ slides. The final paper is hard and the feedback from TA is not useful at all. Be prepared to do 40+ page readings. Most importantly, remember to check your in-class exam since the TA may mark your answer wrong or even miscount your marks

Like others said, has 90+ slides but skips a lot of them even tho theyre tested. The change in paper criteria was very minor. LONG readings but theyre helpful if you dont understand the concepts. 9 page paper was brutal and TA feedback wasn't that helpful. I liked how he encouraged discussion because it was helpful to hear other students thoughts

Throughout the term, the prof would skip more than half of the 90-slide lectures and assigned 40+pgs of reading per week. The slides were not helpful and contained an unnecessary amount of complex language. The final paper was misleading and graded harshly. Tutorials were useless and TAs were of no help.

Jean-christophe isnt as bad as others make him out to be. The 2 midterms were straightforward, he told us what was going to be on them. Lectures are heavy and long readings but if you follow along you'll be good. He's been helpful when I asked for feedback and is knowledgeable about what he teaches. This class is not fun but I would recommend him.

prepare for 90 slides a week that he cant even get thru but u need to know for exams. worst class I have ever taken in HSCI. he goes against everything he says. will admit his outline/marking was wrong but when u ask for him to fix ur grade accordingly, he says no.

this class gives me depression. cant not get a hold of him for help by email and if u talk to him in person the answer is "that isn't ethically fair" even tho he admits he is in the wrong. announced second midterm instead of a paper 3 weeks before it and 2 week before finals. assignment criteria is diff in 3 places so u cant keep track of anything

Grading criteria is unclear, completely unreasonable, and makes no sense. On our last essay, even if you scored the highest in all categories on the rubric, the highest mark you can get is a 92%. Feedback is unhelpful and both prof & TA can't be reached easily. Feels like they just want to screw you over in this class and hope students do poorly.

He's an ok prof, very passionate on the topic. His lectures are way too packed and he ends up running out of time and skipping several slides. Assignments instructions are somewhat unclear but the midterm was fair. Might just be the nature of the class, but his content is very theoretical and doesn't always seem applicable to applied health ethics,

It was his first time teaching. Super energetic and really put in a lot of effort into his class. Very kind and had a lot of practical experience so his lectures and his explanations were more grounded than a lot of profs.
